Industry Shift: The plastic industry would need to adapt to this new reality, focusing on developing biodegradable plastic products or transitioning to other materials. This could lead to the development of more sustainable and eco-friendly products.

Education and Awareness: The biodegradable nature of plastic would raise awareness about the importance of recycling and proper waste management. It would also encourage people to be more mindful of their plastic usage and the impact it has on the environment.

Infrastructure Changes: Cities and municipalities would need to update their waste management systems to accommodate for the rapid degradation of plastic. This could include the development of new recycling facilities and waste-to-energy plants.

Economic Impact: The shift to biodegradable plastics could create new job opportunities in the industry, particularly in the areas of research and development, production, and recycling. It could also lead to the development of new markets and industries focused on sustainable materials.

Material Science Advancements: The need for biodegradable plastics would drive innovation in material science, leading to the development of new materials with similar properties. This could have applications in fields such as medicine, agriculture, and textiles.
